Prompt:
Example 1:
Cat and Dog walk. They walk in their village. Then they see an egg. The egg is in the grass. The egg is alone in the grass. The egg is all alone. Cat and Dog walk to a bird. They ask the bird, "Is this your egg?" But the bird says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the owl. Maybe it is his egg." Cat and Dog walk to the owl. They ask the owl, "Is this your egg?" But the owl says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the goose. Maybe it is her egg." Cat and Dog walk to the goose. They ask the goose, "Is this your egg?" But the goose says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the two ducks. Maybe it is their egg." Cat and Dog walk to the two ducks. They ask the two ducks, "Is this your egg?" But the two ducks say, "No, that is not our egg." Then the egg breaks.

Example 2:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'astronomy' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 100 words.

Astronomy is looking at the sky. It's like a big, dark painting. Stars are like tiny, shiny dots. They're very far away. They twinkle in the night. The Moon is like a big, round cheese. At night, we see the Moon and stars.

"Astronomy is the study of stars, planets, and other objects in the sky. Astronomers use telescopes to look at these objects. They learn about their sizes, colors, and distances. Astronomy is a fun and interesting science to learn about."

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'astronomy' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 100 words. In this paragraph, include at least three types of astronomical objects (e.g., star, planet, galaxy).

Astronomy is about the sky. Look up at night. See the Moon? That's Earth's friend. Stars are like big Suns, far away. Planets go around the Sun. Some planets are close, like Mars. Others are far, like Neptune. Galaxies are like big groups of stars. The Milky Way is our galaxy. It's huge, but we're just a tiny part.

Example 1:
Cat and Dog walk. They walk in their village. Then they see an egg. The egg is in the grass. The egg is alone in the grass. The egg is all alone. Cat and Dog walk to a bird. They ask the bird, "Is this your egg?" But the bird says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the owl. Maybe it is his egg." Cat and Dog walk to the owl. They ask the owl, "Is this your egg?" But the owl says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the goose. Maybe it is her egg." Cat and Dog walk to the goose. They ask the goose, "Is this your egg?" But the goose says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the two ducks. Maybe it is their egg." Cat and Dog walk to the two ducks. They ask the two ducks, "Is this your egg?" But the two ducks say, "No, that is not our egg." Then the egg breaks.

Example 2:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'astronomy' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 100 words. In astronomy, people look at the stars and planets. They see them at night. Stars are tiny, but far away. Planets are big, but close to us. Some planets have no air. They are cold. Some stars are big, but they die. Then they explode. This is called a supernova.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'astronomy' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 100 words. Let's say, 'Cat and Dog are interested in Astronomy'.

Cat and Dog look at the sky. They see many stars. They want to know more about the stars. So they read a book about Astronomy. They learn that stars are big balls of fire. They shine at night. Some stars are close. Others are far away. They learn about the Moon too. It is not a star, but a rock in space. It shines because the Sun lights it up. Cat and Dog like learning about Astronomy. They look forward to seeing more in the night sky.
